title: How to Bring an Off Screen Window Back on Windows

steps.title: Select the off-screen program from your Taskbar.
steps.content: Select the off-screen program from your Taskbar. If the program is running, you'll find it in your Taskbar, which runs along the bottom of your screen. If the program is constantly running like Discord or NIVIDIA Settings, you'll find that under "Show hidden icons" in your system tray, which is where the clock is. You'll see a ^ icon that you need to click). This is a popular solution to fixing this issue in Windows 11 and 10.

steps.title: Press and hold the Win key.
steps.content: Press and hold the Win key. The Windows key looks like the Windows logo on your keyboard. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Press ↑+↓+←+→ keys to move the window back into view.
steps.content: Press ↑ + ↓ + ← + → keys to move the window back into view. It will most likely snap to one of those sides, so you'll want to make it full-screen if you don't want to use it in Split Screen. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Right-click the Windows taskbar.
steps.content: Right-click the Windows taskbar. This is the bar that’s usually at the bottom of the screen, which contains various icons and the Windows button. A menu will appear. This method will not work on Windows 11, as there is no cascade feature.

steps.title: Click Cascade windows or Show windows stacked.
steps.content: Click Cascade windows or Show windows stacked . Both options will display a list of all open windows on your PC, including those currently off-screen. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click the window you want to access.
steps.content: Click the window you want to access. The contents of that window will appear.

steps.title: Hold ⇧ Shift as you right-click the active app on the task bar.
steps.content: Hold ⇧ Shift as you right-click the active app on the task bar. The task bar is the bar that runs along the bottom of the screen. A pop-up menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Move.
steps.content: Click Move . This turns the mouse cursor into an arrow that points in 4 directions.

steps.title: Use the ↑+↓+←+→ keys to move the window back into view.
steps.content: Use the ↑ + ↓ + ← + → keys to move the window back into view. As you tap each directional key, the window will move one step in that direction. Keep tapping the arrows until you’ve come to a good stopping point. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Press Alt+Tab ↹ and release the Tab ↹ key.
steps.content: Press Alt + Tab ↹ and release the Tab ↹ key. Don’t remove your finger from Alt ! You’ll see a list of all open applications on the PC as long as you continue holding Alt .

steps.title: Press Tab ↹ until the window you want to access is selected.
steps.content: Press Tab ↹ until the window you want to access is selected. You should still be holding down the Alt key. You’ll know the window is selected when you see a different colored outline around its edges. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Lift both fingers to move to that window.
steps.content: Lift both fingers to move to that window. The contents of the window now appear on the screen.

steps.title: Hold ⇧ Shift as you right-click the active app on the task bar.
steps.content: Hold ⇧ Shift as you right-click the active app on the task bar. The task bar is the bar that runs along the bottom of the screen. A pop-up menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Move.
steps.content: Click Move . This turns the mouse cursor into an arrow that points in 4 directions.

steps.title: Use the ↑+↓+←+→ keys to move the window back into view.
steps.content: Use the ↑ + ↓ + ← + → keys to move the window back into view. As you tap each directional key, the window will move one step in that direction. Keep tapping the arrows until you’ve come to a good stopping point.

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings. You can open Settings by pressing Win + I together or by clicking the gear icon in the Start menu. Once you have the window set in the middle of your screen, you can reset the resolution of your display.

steps.title: Click System.
steps.content: Click System . This will open the System Settings page. [7] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Display.
steps.content: Click Display . You'll see it in the panel on the left side of the window. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click the drop-down under "Display Resolution" and choose a smaller resolution.
steps.content: Click the drop-down under "Display Resolution" and choose a smaller resolution. In this drop-down, choosing an item lower in the list than the highlighted one (your current settings) will result in a lower resolution. [9] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Your windows will resize and you can press Alt + Tab to activate the missing window and move it where you want it. If you did that in the allotted time (about 15 seconds), you can click Revert . If the time limit has passed, go back to Settings > System > Display > Display Resolution and change it back to the recommended setting.
